senses.sense_definition: Strong disagreement with a plan, policy, or action, or the act of trying to stop it.

examples.text: The new construction project faced strong <w>opposition</w> from the local residents.
She remained in <w>opposition</w> to the committee's decision despite the pressure.

senses.sense_definition: The main political party or group that is not in power and opposes the government.

examples.text: The leader of the <w>opposition</w> criticized the prime minister's speech in parliament.
The <w>opposition</w> voted against the proposed budget cuts.

senses.sense_definition: The state of being placed opposite or being completely different from something else.

examples.text: His calm behavior stood in direct <w>opposition</w> to his brother's anger.
The two theories are in <w>opposition</w> regarding the cause of the phenomenon.

senses.sense_definition: The position of a planet when it is directly opposite the sun as seen from Earth.

examples.text: Mars will reach <w>opposition</w> next week, making it visible all night long.
Astronomers get the best view of a planet when it is in <w>opposition</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A situation in chess where the kings face each other with one square in between, forcing the other player to move.

examples.text: He used the <w>opposition</w> to force the enemy king away from the pawn.
Understanding how to gain the <w>opposition</w> is crucial for winning endgames.

senses.sense_definition: A legal process in which someone tries to prevent a trademark or patent from being registered.

examples.text: The company filed an <w>opposition</w> to the competitor's new trademark.
They have thirty days to file a notice of <w>opposition</w> with the patent office.

senses.sense_definition: The relationship between two logical statements that have the same subject and predicate but differ in quantity or quality.

examples.text: The square of <w>opposition</w> is a diagram used to teach classical logic.
In logic, <w>opposition</w> determines whether two statements can both be true at the same time.
